data.title: Launch: first argument for workspace path no longer reaches extension window
data.body:
I am no longer able to launch an extension on a specific workspace. To reproduce:
- generate an extension
- open launch.json
- add a folder to open as first argument

=> the folder is not opened in the window that opens the extension
- add the folder again so that it shows up as the first two entries in the arguments

=> now the folder is opened

@weinand @isidorn any ideas?

data.title: Disable middle-click paste
data.body: Some of us are used to middle-click not pasting so it is very annoying for it to paste into the editor on Linux.  There should be a config option to disable middle-click paste.

data.title: Tabs not rendering right
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open some tabs
2. Close VSCode
3. Re-open VSCode

Minor issue, I know, but still strange.
Looks like that, when opened, VSCode tries to fit all tabs in the given space.
When I click on one of the unselected tabs, the rendering starts to work and the horizontal scrollbar appears.

Freshly opened
https://i.imgsafe.org/2239ae0c43.png

After click
https://i.imgsafe.org/223ac7eb7f.png

data.title: Debugger tool uninstalled not disappeared or disabled
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 SP1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install Python (or whatever you will use to debug) extension and restart VS Code.
2. Select it as a debug tool, run it and do whatever.
3. Uninstall it and restart
4. Debug tool will be visible and not disabled to run debugger on it.

Thanks

data.title: Handle spaces in text mate rule name

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It looks like text mate rule names can have space:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/python/syntaxes/MagicPython.tmLanguage.json#L1712

The typescript grammar now also uses such rules and we should handle them.
Looking on how TextMate shows them, they are just treated as two different scopes on the stack.

This fix could be done in vscode-textmate or in vscode.
@alexandrudima Let me know if you want me to have a look

data.title: TypeScript formatter suddenly forgets about formatting rules
data.body:
While developing on Code's source code, the following has happened to me twice: as I edit a file, the language service somehow forgets about the formatting rules and starts formatting everything with 4 spaces, [instead of a tab](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/tsfmt.json#L5).

@jrieken suggests that

> yes - typescript has forgotten to which project your file belongs and now uses default settings (from the default project)
> this happens after a rebase/sync/etc
> restart typescript server and youll be happy again

This happened during regular coding, I did not mess with rebase/sync. It literally changed mid-edit. Reloading the TypeScript didn't fix it. Only reloading the window did.

data.title: [C++] single quotes in numeric literals are parsed incorrectly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:

Open a `.cpp` file with a literal with a single quote in it:

``` c++
constexpr int a = 100'000;

int main() {}
```

Expected result: The main function should be highlighted as normal.
Actual result: Everything after the single quote is formatted as if it was in a string literal.

See [integer literal](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/integer_literal) (and [floating point literal](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/floating_literal)) on cppreference for the details about numeric literals in C++.

data.title: Debug: Extra whitespace when showing object variable inline
Investigate to leverage accessibility API in Electron
data.body:
Since we are on Electron 1.3.x there is more API support to find out if a screen reader is attached or not. The related API is:
- `accessibility-support-changed` [event](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/api/app.md#event-accessibility-support-changed-macos-windows)
- a new [method](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/api/app.md#appisaccessibilitysupportenabled-macos-windows) `app.isAccessibilitySupportEnabled()`

I verified that these work on Windows and Mac. On Mac the event works when changing the native screen reader (Cmd+F5). On Windows I tried with NVDA and the only thing that was not working is that the event would fire when turning OFF NVDA, but turning ON was ok.

@alexandrudima I think you expressed some interest in this, so I am moving this to you first to see if we want to use it. I can then look into how to surface this API as workbench API for you.

data.title: Window title not updated on Open Recent
data.body:

  Version 1.6.0
  Commit e25fb0bc
  Shell 1.3.7
  Renderer 52.0.2743.82
  Node 6.5.0
- OS Version:
  Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Visual studio code such that it opens the last opened project
2. File -> Open Recent
3. Select a recent project

Expected behaviour:

Window title reflects the name of the newly opened folder

Actual behaviour: 

Window title remains as the first opened project

data.title: Add Char to status bar (besides Line and Col)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T15:43:46.054Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.7.0-1-amd64
- Extensions: donjayamanne.githistory-0.1.0, donjayamanne.python-0.5.0, felipecaputo.git-project-manager-0.1.15, formulahendry.auto-close-tag-0.3.4, ms-vscode.cpptools-0.9.2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a new file
2. If indentation is set to spaces, click the "Spaces" button in the bottom status bar to switch to tab indentation, and a tab size of 4.
3. Into the empty file, enter `[tab]23456789` (where "[tab]" is a tab character)
4. Click the Ln/Col indicator in the status bar and go to position 1,5 (line 1, column 5)
5. The cursor will now be placed between "4" and "5", indicating that the "go to line,col" command treated the tab as 1 "column", but the line/col indicator in the status bar shows "Ln 1, Col 8", indicating that it treats the tab as 4 "columns".

I can't say which is correct -- treating a tab as 1 "column" or treating it as 4 "columns" (if it is represented as 4 spaces), but my feeling is that the former is better (compilers and the like would report character counts with tabs only counting as 1, right?). However, it's clear that whichever mode should be used, the goto command and the line/column indicator should be consistent.
